Question: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in an unsorted array? (Theoretical)
What is the advantage of arrays in terms of accessing elements? (Understanding)
What is the result of sorting an array before performing a binary search? (Pseudocode)
Correct Answer: C) O(n log n) time complexity

Question: What is the disadvantage of doubly linked lists compared to singly linked lists? (Understanding)
What is the time complexity of summing elements in an array using a simple algorithm? (Pseudocode)
What is the primary advantage of binary search trees over arrays? (Theoretical)
What is the property of a Max-Heap that ensures finding the maximum element can be done in constant time? (Theoretical)
Option A: The value of each node is less than or equal to the values of its children
Option B: The value of each node is greater than or equal to the values of its children
Option C: The value of each node is equal to the values of its children
Option D: The value of each node is less than the values of its children
Correct Answer: B) The value of each node is greater than or equal to the values of its children

Question: What is the purpose of balanced trees like AVL and Red-Black trees? (Theoretical)
Option A: To reduce the height of the tree
Option B: To increase the height of the tree
Option C: To maintain the height of the tree as small as possible
Option D: To increase the number of nodes in the tree
Correct Answer: C) To maintain the height of the tree as small as possible

Question: What is the time complexity of insertion and deletion operations in a balanced binary search tree? (Theoretical)
What is the advantage of arrays in terms of memory efficiency? (Understanding)
What is the disadvantage of arrays in terms of insertion and deletion? (Understanding)
What is the application of linked lists in memory management systems? (Remembering)
Option A: Dynamic allocation and freeing of memory blocks
Correct Answer: A) Dynamic allocation and freeing of memory blocks

Question: What is the characteristic of a binary search tree that allows for fast lookup operations? (Theoretical)
Option A: The value of the left child is greater than its parent node
Option B: The value of the right child is less than its parent node
Option C: The value of the left child is less than its parent node and the value of the right child is greater than its parent node
Option D: The value of the left child is equal to its parent node
Correct Answer: C) The value of the left child is less than its parent node and the value of the right child is greater than its parent node

Question: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a binary search tree? (Theoretical)
What is the application of heaps in real-world scenarios? (Remembering)
Correct Answer: B) Priority queues and scheduling systems
